country.name: Guernsey
country.background: Guernsey and the other Channel Islands represent the last remnants of the medieval Dukedom of Normandy, which held sway in both France and England. The islands were the only British soil occupied by German troops in World War II. Guernsey is a British crown dependency but is not part of the UK or of the European Union. However, the UK Government is constitutionally responsible for its defense and international representation.

geo.note: large, deepwater harbor at Saint Peter Port

location.desc: Western Europe, islands in the English Channel, northwest of France

area.comparison: about one-half the size of Washington, DC

geo.climate: temperate with mild winters and cool summers; about 50% of days are overcast
geo.terrain: mostly level with low hills in southwest

people.ethnic-groups: British and Norman-French descent with small percentages from other European countries
people.religions: Anglican, Roman Catholic, Presbyterian, Baptist, Congregational, Methodist
people.languages: English, French, Norman-French dialect spoken in country districts

capital.name: Saint Peter Port
capital.time-difference: UTC 0 (5 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.administrative-divisions: none (British crown dependency); there are no first-order administrative divisions as defined by the US Government, but there are 10 parishes: Castel, Forest, Saint Andrew, Saint Martin, Saint Peter Port, Saint Pierre du Bois, Saint Sampson, Saint Saviour, Torteval, Vale
government.legal-system: customary legal system based on Norman customary law, and includes elements of the French Civil Code and English common law

executive.head-of-state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952), represented by Lieutenant Governor Air Marshall Peter WALKER (since 15 April 2011)
executive.head-of-government: Chief Minister Lyndon TROTT (since 1 May 2008); Bailiff Sir Geoffrey ROWLAND (since June 2005)
executive.cabinet: Policy Council elected by the States of Deliberation
executive.elections: the monarchy is hereditary; lieutenant governor and bailiff appointed by the monarch; chief minister elected by States of Deliberation
executive.election-results: Lyndon TROTT elected chief minister, percent of vote of the States of Deliberation NA

legislative.description: unicameral States of Deliberation (45 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms; note - there are also 10 Douzaine representatives - one from each parish, 2 representatives from Alderney and the appointed attorney general and soliciter general); note - Alderney and Sark have parliaments
legislative.elections: last held on 23 April 2008 (next to be held in 2012)
legislative.election-results: percent of vote - NA; seats - all independents

government.judicial: Royal Court (judges elected by an electoral college and the bailiff)
government.flag: white with the red cross of Saint George (patron saint of England) extending to the edges of the flag and a yellow equal-armed cross of William the Conqueror superimposed on the Saint George cross; the red cross represents the old ties with England and the fact that Guernsey is a British Crown dependency; the gold cross is a replica of the one used by Duke William of Normandy at the Battle of Hastings

economy.overview: Financial services - banking, fund management, insurance - account for about 23% of employment and about 55% of total income in this tiny, prosperous Channel Island economy. Tourism, manufacturing, and horticulture, mainly tomatoes and cut flowers, have been declining. Financial services, construction, retail, and the public sector have been growing. Light tax and death duties make Guernsey a popular tax haven. The evolving economic integration of the EU nations is changing the environment under which Guernsey operates.
economy.agriculture-products: tomatoes, greenhouse flowers, sweet peppers, eggplant, fruit; Guernsey cattle

exports.commodities: tomatoes, flowers and ferns, sweet peppers, eggplant, other vegetables

imports.commodities: coal, gasoline, oil, machinery and equipment

telephones.domestic: fixed-line and mobile-cellular services widely available; combined fixed and mobile-cellular teledensity exceeds 100 per 100 persons

communications.broadcast: multiple UK terrestrial television broadcasts - received via a transmitter in Jersey with relays in Jersey, Guernsey, and Alderney - will begin switching from analog to digital broadcasts in November 2010; satellite packages are available; BBC Radio Guernsey and 1 other radio station operating (2009)

manpower.notes: defense is the responsibility of the UK
